First, let's understand the terms validity and reliability. Validity refers to how well a test measures what it is purported to measure. In this case, it refers to how close the new method's measurements are to the standard calorimetry measurement of 10.2. Reliability refers to the consistency of a measure. In this case, it refers to how consistent the new method's measurements are. Looking at the data, the measurements from the new method range from 9.1 to 12.1. The mean of these measurements is approximately 10, which is close to the standard calorimetry measurement of 10.2. This suggests that the new method has high validity. However, the measurements from the new method are quite spread out, ranging from 9.1 to 12.1. This suggests that the new method has low reliability, as the measurements are not very consistent. Therefore, the new method has high validity and low reliability. So, the answer is B. High validity, low reliability.
